instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B BIOS crashing
threads.message:
Hello everybody

I m working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B some one worked on it. When come to my desk fan spinning but not chime not mouse led... after rewrite BOIS board turned on for 3-5 time ( screen come back and mouse led on) after few reboot stopped again and turned at start problem . Replaced  bios chip 3 time and all the time same issue. ( SMC looking like replaced i cant be sure is it correct SMC). 

Any suggestion for solve problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B BIOS crashing
threads.message: Where did you get the bios file??? It has a clean ME region???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B BIOS crashing
threads.message: I hope you still have the original backup!?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B BIOS crashing
threads.message: I have clean me file known good also used before this board and worked without problem. Yes i have original bios file backup.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B BIOS crashing
threads.message: Something else is reacting to the heat. Put back original file and check all SPI termination resistors. Look for corrosion around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area and pin 8 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
